And I love that they can do something they like--talk with Alexa--and it gets them to actively listen and engage. I know this makes me sound old, but so many digital distractions seem designed to help kids disengage. Also, the book options are great.

title: Appropriate game play for elementary school ages. Allows player to name and raise a baby panda.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2018
content: This fun, interactive game begins by introducing you to the Panda Sanctuary in Wolong, and explains that as a volunteer you must help raise a baby panda to be released in the wild. Throughout the game, the single player proceeds through levels and earns points for correct answers that lead to a healthy and happy adult panda. The player is first introduced to a companion, Ivy, who is also a volunteer. Ivy appears repeatedly to deliver advice, facts, or to help game play.The player starts with a newborn and gets to choose whether it is male or female, and then gets to name the panda. Correct answers and decisions result in the panda learning a crucial life skill. After completing each level, the player chooses whether to continue or come back tomorrow. After 9 levels of play, the baby panda has fully grown and has all of the skills it needs to be released into the wild.If the player doesn't answer the questions correctly, a Sanctuary Officer appears and gives a three-question quiz. We encountered a bit of a glitch during this section as the questions repeated, but the "correct" answers differed in two turns. Not answering the questions correctly leads to the Sanctuary Officer giving you one caution. Three cautions will cost you the game.Instant feedback on answers is given with a combination of a tone and verbal acknowledgement. Point totals are given after each question, as well as at the completion of each level. Remediation isn't consistent, but when offered, is in the form of a hint rather than explicitly giving the right answer.  Playing the game all the way through takes around 45 minutes, so for smaller children this might be better broken into a daily game time.

title: Love it - great immersive experience, well written & performed
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2021
content: We love this skill.  My 6 year old uses it everyday to save the Panda, Turtle and Tiger.  It has engaging actors and sounds effects that make it seem "real".  The choice options are given simply so you don't run into the fuzzy language issues (so my kid isn't screaming "the bamboo" at Alexa 7 times when it wants "bamboo plant." like other skills we have issues with) It also has chapters so you can pause play.  AND it remember where you stopped so you can start it again later.  Very helpful when you have a kid who loves it but needs to do other things once and a while :DAlso - we never paid or were asked to pay for extra sessions - they were all there (Turtle, Panda, Tiger) once I enabled the skill.To the developers: you asked for suggestions for other animals - my son's request: cheetahs, elephants and whales

title: Fun and engaging experience for 7-10 year olds
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2018
content: The game takes you through raising a baby panda until it is ready to be released into the wild. The narration and audio complement each other really well and create an immersive environment, with sound effects of the refuge and the forest. You can even hear your baby panda playing. I learned a lot about pandas, and the knowledge I gained is going to stick, because they were talking about my own personal baby panda. Unlike other voice-enabled stories, this one is very straightforward, and any child over the age of 6-7 will have no problem navigating through it.This is a really lovely, gentle game for kids!

title: Back off.

content: Apparently you underestimate how hostile I would be towards having advertisements shouted at me from my echo.If I want a skill, then I’ll look for it. I don’t even have kids.I hope you find this review as obnoxious as I found you echo ad.5 stars? GFY

title: Entertaining for older kids and parents as well.
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2018
content: I'd love to give this five stars and I hope soon I can... as I know this is a new product.Here are the reasons its only 4. *grins*Many times questions are answered correctly by the player and they are told wrong, and given the answer just given. OR. Asked same question again, answered correctly again, called faulty again. We would even be careful of how we said it.There is no way to just pause this game. It is either a total focus, or a you have to reopen the game. Any pause kicks you out. And plays the "please review." which I am glad to hear, so I review. But not glad to be kicked out when I need to talk to my kid. Or ask him to do something. A total pause would be AWESOME.  You could even end it with a please review or some such.Ivy baby talks.I would hate my toddler to be learning baby talk from something teaching them.And we Quickly found it annoying.My 10 yo started this game, we've been anxious for fun games on Alexa, and me the 12 yo joined in. Both of my sons found this game fun and cute.  And both would like more levels. So would I. this is adorable.I would love it if you would PLEASE give us multiple accounts? So that we could each raise one.It was very cute and taught all of us a lot about Panda's and I'd love to see more games likeThe over all is that this is an awesome game for this early in development. Please expand more and I can't wait for updates.

title: Not What It Used To Be

content: The new version of animal sounds is horrible. The sounds are too short, they do not tell you what animal it is. It used to say, “here comes a bear sound”. title: Pointless, too much talking
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 22, 2020
content: Alexa used to just make animal sounds on command, now you have to use this skill? Alexa talks more than she makes animal sounds. This is terrible, just make the sounds when I ask so my toddler can hear an elephant!

title: add my voice to the chorus. absolutely horrible update. almost no animal sounds
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 13, 2022
content: It used to play animal sounds, now it's all airplane noises as it jumps around continent to continent and facts about the animal only to play 2 seconds of actual animal sounds, if you're lucky.Who is this for, exactly? What person who cares about these facts wants to hear them and hear them from Alexa? Would that same person be interested in taking an audio-only "trip" around the world using bad airplane sounds?On top of all of that, when this app/skill was good, it would ask if you wanted to hear another animal sound and my toddler could say "yes.". Now it asks you to say "continue" to keep going. Ugh.

title: Won't disable...or SHUT UP!!!
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 17, 2021
content: I enabled this skill to make a llama sound...and Alexa doesn't know what a llama is, or the sound it makes (should I have asked for an Alpaca sound instead???)  Now Alexa won't shut up even though I disabled Animal Sounds in my Alexa Assistant and my house sounds like a barnyard as she tries to get me to tell her what animal sounds she is playing.  VERY AGGRAVATING.

title: What used to work is now a disaster
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 6, 2020
content: This used to be great for my autistic son we could ask “play (animal) sounds” or “what sound does an (animal) make?” And Alexa would play the sound he was looking for. Now we dread when he wants to use this app because it doesn’t just play the animal sound it goes through a list of animals or makes an airplane noise that he has an aversion to when “flying” to where the animal is from. When Alexa does not play the animal sound as it used to he typically is distressed and enacts self injurious behavior. This was something simple and fun for kids where they could name an animal and ask for the sound, now it’s a headache every time.

title: Just play the sound.
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 11, 2020
content: “Alexa, ask aninal sounds what an elephant sounds like.” is too long to begin with and then Alexa says, “I don’t know that one. Would you like to open the app animal sounds?” And then the app animal sounds opens… And there’s a whooooioole lot more to say. My two-year-old just wants to hear an elephant.

title: Too stressful at times
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 31, 2016
content: Well,  she is very impatient,  especially when I am trying this with my grandchildrens times tables. Also,  her 18 doesn't sound like 18 and some numbers that we get correct are not heard from her.  If you want her to repeat the question she will,  but you are more worried about her shutting off and it doesn't help with the multiplication challenges at hand. Lend people more time to think and they will probably get the answers faster with less stress.

title: Great Skill with a Major Drawback
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 24, 2016
content: This skill has some really wonderful features - the parameters you can set, the fact that she'll repeat a question if it's not answered, all of it.Unfortunately, its voice recognition seems decidedly more persnikkity than that with both native apps and the other skills we've tried. At first, I thought it was an issue with my 3rd grader's still-childlike voice, but she often doesn't register my answers, either.I'm not sure how much the developer's code can impact this, but it does seem like something is off. If this can be improved, this will be a 5-star skill.

title: Easy to use and REALLY helpful
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 28, 2020
content: LiveHint provides accessible support in the form of hints to students AND PARENTS as they complete Practice problems in textbook Assignments. It doesn't give away the answers, and students still have to think--and it works really well if you try to solve the problem before asking for hints as they suggest. The mobile app version is pictured (at livehint.com).

title: Win for students and parents!
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 28, 2020
content: LiveHint offers great support to students and parents working at home on their Carnegie Learning homework! The detailed hints give students information that they need to complete the Practice questions in the assignments, while still learning the math.

title: A huge help

date: Reviewed in the United States on June 4, 2020
content: Might be okay for 3-4 year -olds. Of course,  Elena has a hard enough time understanding adults, so maybe not. My 7 year-old wanted to practice her subtraction. The app was still asking, "What is 3-2?" on level 5. Level 5 is as high as it goes, but there isn't any noticeable difference between any of the levels. I would have given it 1 ☆ , but we didn't try the multiplication or division. the second star is because I didn't want to judge the parts we didn't try.

skillname: Kids Word of the Day Flash Briefing
title: Still liking this skill... because the developers listened to feedback
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 14, 2018
content: UPDATE:  I'm pleased to report the developers are listening to user feedback. It is easier to listen to and self-contained for listeners who may not tune in every single day.  We complained when we couldn't understand the hosts, and they cleared it up.  We complained when they removed the spelling, and they added it back in.  Kudos to Volley for trying to give users what they want.  My original review is belowA long-time listener to the grown-up WOTD version, I was quick to add the kids' version when it launched.  While at first I felt the show was just a bit long with the riddle and pun-filled characters, I soon realized that charm was just what kids need to activate their brains and get focused.  What really impressed me though is the mnemonic aids built in to the broadcast that will subtly assist them in remembering the word itself: repetition is obvious, but the use of a musical scale during the spelling portion to chunk large data and sequence it?  That's genius.  Now if I could just find a way to play just this briefing instead of the whole flash update when I want to share it with my classroom this fall, I'd be all set!

skillname: Kids Word of the Day Flash Briefing
title: It WAS great
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2018
content: I used to enjoy their program but I believe they stopped their production. They kept repeating the same old episodes over and over, so I finally deleted them from my briefing.> Original Review <I love love love this flash briefing! I’m an adult and English is not my first language. I’ve been looking for English learning skills/flash briefings but I haven’t found anything that made me want to stick with. This one is short, fun and very useful.I took a star off because... 1. Please spell out the word. I believe it’s very important. 2. Although I love that you bring in special guests, many of them mumble and I don’t understand them. Because this show is for learning, I hope the guests could speak out a bit more clearly.With those improvements, this show can easily get 100 stars! Also, please consider developing a kids idiom of the day flash briefing. I think you can make another funny show. “Cold turkey? Whaaat??”

skillname: Kids Word of the Day Flash Briefing
title: No more incomprehensible voices! Yay!
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2018
content: We listen to Kids Word of the Day each morning while waiting for the bus, so the information needs to be concise.  The developers must have listened to the bad reviews because lately we haven't had any "guests".  I was considering deleting this skill, but the current format is clear and efficient, even with the time used for the riddles. The riddles are not easy and I like listening to my children discuss their guesses and reasoning behind them.

skillname: Kids Word of the Day Flash Briefing
title: Good vocabulary builder, fun, but...
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2018
content: When we began listening, Finn McCool and Marion Webster provided nice, comprehensible riddles and definitions. Over the past several weeks guest hosts such as "Bane," "Snape," and "Yoda" have been bringing us words instead. This would be great, if they didn't sound like they were speaking thru a mouth full of marbles from the bottom of the ocean. Seriously, I can't understand more than 1 word in 3. Thankfully the host repeats most definitions in a clear tone, but  I was tired of the guests three weeks ago. Even the kids (5 thru 9) are frustrated now.

skillname: Kids Word of the Day Flash Briefing

title: Educational and deeply engaging for kids
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2019
content: Since I do not have a television at home, it is sometimes difficult to keep kids engaged beyond a point (I run out of storytelling abilities after the first seven minutes or so). Last evening, my five-year-friend (neighbor) was visiting (her mother had some chores to deal with)—and after exhausting the Dr Seuss book, and a couple of stories, I turned on this new skill on impulse! It took the child a minute to get the hang of it—and she was totally engaged for the next half hour. Each passage had a bunch of questions—and the child sat there chatting patiently with ‘Alexa’—the first time in the evening she just sat in one place and answered questions instead of asking them! When her mother arrived, she was in the middle of the skeleton costume story—and the mother was a little surprised when her daughter announced: Mamma—you have 206 bones! Yup—I would highly recommend this skill. Edutainment? Is that what they call it?

title: Enabled the skill and enabled my kid!
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 21, 2020
content: This app has given my son (who has never naturally gravitated to reading as much as other subjects such as math, to my frustration) -- but the interactivity (it asks basic questions about the passage which my son can answer) is enough to  make it  engaging. He is well on his way to building a passion for reading. A++

title: Who does not love Highlights?

I remember how happy I was when I knew the answer to Highlights problems--and now so do they.

title: Critical Life Skills
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2020
content: Bamboo English has self-paced exercises (many free) for kids K-5 to learn and practice skills such as phonics, spelling, grammar, and vocabulary. You can begin with a 14-day trial and then there is a modest monthly subscription fee.  Track up to 6 kids per family and monitor their individual progress!  If I had children, especially during this time of much remote learning, this seems like the right tool at the right time.

title: Just what the teacher ordered
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2020
content: The Bamboo family of products was already great for teaching and supplementing learning before we were doing school from home. It's now essential in my mind. It works for kids of many ages, is fun and easy for kids but also effective in actually teaching them, and doesn't require constant supervision by parents. I appreciate that some skills, like Bamboo English, are designed off of actual school curricula to keep kids on track. I like to use it with different Alexa devices  - Echo, Fire TV and Fire tablet at my house - but also on my phone. I learn from it too while the kids listen.  Super thoughtfully designed and useful products, hence, earned my time to write a long review.

title: Great app for kid's to learn at home!

reviewer: Teachers of blind and visually impaired students, NYC
title: Great app for learning and reinforcing basic Math skills. Immediate feedback provided.
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 5, 2020
content: I was contacted by one of the apps founders for our school to be part of a trial. Our students are legally blind and we are trying it in our K-3 classes. Misha, the cofounder I have been working with, has been 100% supportive.  He trained me and our staff by webinar and communicates regularly with us. We are currently out of school in NY  due to the Corona Virus, but we will continua using it once we are back. In the meantime if students have an Alexa device at home, they can continue using it. Great for learning and practicing basic Math skills and new skills are  being added.

title: Our students love it!
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2020
content: I have been using this skill in class of B/VI students for a couple of months now. The kids (K and 1st grade) took to it quickly and seem to enjoy this way of practicing their basic facts. For the blind child it's a matter of audio interaction that makes it more a way of play than work, but hey, it works.I'm includin this skill in our schools distance learning suggestions as we are currently one of those affected by the current pandmeic situation.

title: Fun way to practice math facts
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2020
content: I am a teacher and I used Thinking Cap Math in a small group pull out with two students who were learning 3rd grade math. The students thought the app was really funny.  I kept them engaged - so much so that they asked to do it every day!  As a teacher I loved that they were working on their ability to manipulate numbers.  One session led us to a teaching moment about decomposing numbers.  Both the students and I found this app to be great!

title: Great skill to sharpen math skills
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2020
content: Such a great skill! My 6 years old boy practiced additions and counting, and asked for more! Wonderful skill to sharpen math skills

title: Really well done!
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 5, 2019
content: We have a third grader and a K student, and we were so happy to discover this skill. We have them use it a couple of times a week and I really see how their math skills are improving. For example our daughter, just turned 7, now knows all the combinations of 7, 8, 9 and 10! I feel like the creators really put a lot of thought into how to present the material to a child. My favorite part is the math stories, which are seriously hilarious. And when my kids make mistakes, it never says "Wrong answer!", but just tries to lead them to a correct answer. I thought that was perfect. And even for our third grader it is a great way to recap the basics, like working on how to add numbers quickly, up to 20. Overall a great app. I'm on the PTO, so I have been telling everyone at school about this app!

title: Does the job!
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 5, 2021
content: Like many on here, we have reminders and routines for our son's classes. Everything from "Log into Teams and get ready for your next class" to "Spanish is about to start. You got this." But there was something missing. The good ol' school bell.Did a quick search yesterday and found this skill, with lackluster reviews. Don't knock it 'til you try it, I always say. So I installed this skill, made a quick test routine and worked flawlessly within a couple of minutes.Here's how:1. Install skill2. Create New Routine3. Choose Routine name4. When this happens / Schedule / At Time / Weekdays + Select the time you want the bell to play.5. Add Action / Custom / Alexa says:"ask school bell to ring".6. Select the Alexa speaker that's gonna play the bells.7. Enjoy!*Nitpick, sounds like a fire station's bell, but it does the job. Hence the 4/5 stars.

title: Perfect for our homeschool needs!
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 6, 2021
content: As others have complained about this, I was unsure if it would work. But as another reviewer suggested, when setting this routine do NOT have Alexa open this skill as the action. This will only have her ask you if you want to play the school bell. Do this instead:1. Add Action2. Custom3. Type in “ask school bell to ring”Alexa will automatically play the school bell for your set day/time.

title: Isn't helpful
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 12, 2020
content: I want to schedule times for it to ring, like in routines. but when I play the routine, it doesn't ring, it asks me if I'd like to ring the bell. If I have to tell it to ring a bell, I might as well just tell my kids it's time to start school.

title: Not very useful
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2020
content: This would be helpful if it actually worked and if you could set up times for things like the start of school, recess and lunch breaks. as it is its cumbersom and not very helpful.

title: Why does Alexa need to ask me if I scheduled her to do it?
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 5, 2021
content: The bell is fine.  Sounds close enough to a school bell to work for our early morning homeschool routine.  However, I have it set as a scheduled routine in Alexa (every morning at 8:30am) and every Alexa still asks every morning "would you like the ring the school bell?  Tell me to ring the school bell" and repeats this until you say "ring the bell".  Why?  I wouldn't have scheduled it if I wasn't sure I needed it and I honestly can't imagine another purpose for this other than home/remote schooling.  Honestly, the Amazon Alexa developers could just put a school bell in the sound selection on Alexa and this 'skill' would be obsolete pretty quickly, but they haven't, so I have been using it.  I'll change my rating if the 3rd party dev who put this together updates before the end of the school year.

title: Be prepared to supply credit card authorization # - I wouldn't do it!
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 6, 2018
content: Poor choice in requiring personal credit information prior to enabling.  I (an adult) was asked for my Amazon sign in ... which I supplied.  Next, I was asked for the 3-digit authorization code for my credit card ... which I absolutely would not supply online.  Why in the world would anyone think of asking for this information?  Whether it is an innocent request or not, I think it bears skepticism, and I would suggest that the developers rethink their requirement for proving one's identity.

title: Works great so far
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2019
content: I briefly sampled this for about 10 minutes and it interprets spelling fine. it does give you a good bit of time to start spelling the word but once you start any brief pause and it will assume you're done, which might frustrate a kid but I think will promote better mastery once they get a hang of it. I noticed complaints about homophones but the words are actually said in the dialogue just prior, (which doesnt repeat)  so you just have to pay attention to context. i.e. if the character will say something like "I am bored of this."

title: great game, some confusing aspects
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 27, 2020
content: My daughter has mixed feelings, it does not allow for enough time once you start speaking or if you cough or sneeze or your mean mom accidently talks to you during the game, it does not know the difference between this and an actual misspelling. It also is not ever clear which version of a word it is looking for, it would be cute if for words that are homonyms there was a little mini insult to create context. We have also had multiple occasions where we spell something correctly but our dialet is not understood, it is super discouraging for a 7 year-old who is actually a pretty good speller most of the time. Things I love as a parent, this keeps her busy and away from a screen, she is engaged, laughing and learning new words. It just needs some updating.

skillname: Red Riding Hood - Interactive story for kids
title: Not for kids under the age of 5!
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2020
content: Red Riding Hood is a story for children. But there is an ending that might upset them. The Big Bad Wolf dresses as Emilia’s/Red Riding Hood’s Grandma and lures Red Riding Hood OR Emilia into Grandma’s House. How to get the ending is to pick the choice: “Give Grandma the basket” and then the Big Bad Wolf Say’s “Mmmmmm! Cheese! Yummy, bread!” and Red Riding Hood says: “What is your third favorite Grandma?” and the Big Bad Wolf Says “LITTLE GIRLS!” and the Big Bad Wolf killed Red Riding Hood. No offense but, this should be banned from the Amazon App. If any kids under the age of 5 that sees this review, I suggest not to play the interactive story!

skillname: Red Riding Hood - Interactive story for kids
title: Fun story but frustrating for kids
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 7, 2019
content: My kids really like sitting and listening to this story! They love that the story changes based on their choices... BUT Alexa doesnt always understand their choice when they speak it to her, which would be fine except that it automatically restarts the whole stinking section!! Why wouldnt it just give them another chance to respond?!

title: Fantastic skill but needs one small change...
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 25, 2019
content: The game is seriously great, but my 6 year old was very upset when she moved on so quickly after giving the answer options. My son is ADHD so it takes him some time to listen and respond. He knew the answer, but after about 5 seconds she repeats the question. If he still can’t answer in time, she closes the game. I just feel a better idea would be to allow the user to set the amount of time to answer (10, 20, 30 seconds). Otherwise, great skill!

title: My daughter enjoys it!
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2020
content: We have a great time with both the question of the day and kids quiz. I like how she gets to select the category and if she doesn't like any of them.. she just has to tough it out and learn about something she didn't know before!Having to have Alexa repeat right after the choices for answers are given is a little awkward, a 15-30 second pause for her to think about what the answer is would be a great feature. Maybe have a lighting round where you have to answer quick or the option to set a "think" time would be great. It is a little hard to discuss the question with her while Alexa is repeating.Or maybe a wait command, that would be great.

title: Ring and Echo Not an Easy Match

content: Device is not simple to setup. Echo wont download the Ring app nor the Alexa app to access. I found that the only way to see the Ring devices was with Alexa and Ring apps on my Ipad pro. Deleting video and snapshots from the doorbell is a ridiculously arduous process. The Ring security system sold on amazon, bestbuy and direct from Ring funnels you into the 8 piece system version 2 and does tell you that there is a better version with eero mesh wifi for $50 more saving a huge cost for an eero base with 802.11ac wifi 6.

title: Bustin' Makes Me Feel Good (and so does this Skill)!
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 14, 2019
content: A fun skill that allows you to interact with a team of rookie ghostbusters, out to prove that they can bust ghosts with the best of them.  Like most Alexa skills, it's audio-dominated, but a screened device will display some visuals as well.It’s not necessary to be familiar with the movies in order to play this game, but fans of the GB franchise should get a kick out of hearing Dan Aykroyd as Ray Stantz and Ernie Hudson as Winston Zeddemore talking to them, plus other familiar references from the film that you’ll have to find out for yourself.This is an enjoyable skill with great replay value  -- if you play a ghost busting mission at the same location over again, you will likely get different encounters from the ones you got the first time.  And even if you do get the same encounter, you can always make different choices and end up with an alternate outcome (some of which are downright hilarious).  It’s like “Choose Your Own Adventure” – Ghostbusters style.Now go out there and bust some ghosts!

title: The Favorite So Far
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2019
content: My 6yr old is constantly playing this game. It gets very hot here in the desert and this one keeps her entertained for hours until cool enough to go back outside again. Please, please, please add more!! Maybe even just one feature added to each location? A different animal calling in the kitchen, a fruit to pick off the farm?I did notice one bug. When she was asking for the peanut butter and jelly sandwich in the kitchen, it would think she said goodbye or stop or something. Even i'll say it and she'll think i'm saying bye? Also, we play restaurant and the dialog goes really fast, maybe slow it down or start by saying what they will need for each recipe? We will need 1 spoon, 1 cup, 1 cup of chocolate powder, and some marshmallows? Anyways, the bugs are by far worth it and for the fun and pretend! Thank you! She's a huge fan!

date: Reviewed in the United States on July 28, 2019

Thank you Little Tikes for getting my kids to use their imaginations and play together.

title: Not so great...
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2020
content: It tells good stories, but it’s not a good tool for trying to get your child to sleep. Every minute or so it prompts them to answer a question or do something , and if they don’t answer it will turn off, so their focus has to be on it and they have to constantly talk. It’s not a good way to relax them, and the stories are not the best quality. Three stars because it will at least keep my daughter entertained.

title: Great use of Echo Show and shows huge pot
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 21, 2018
content: This is a great skill for the Echo Show. I played it with my five year old and we had fun for a few games.Pro’s - graphics are very colorful, gameplay is simple but effective. Sounds that are incorporated are age appropriate.Con’s - Using the term “zoo time” constantly throws off the device as time is a reserved word and starts the timer, or states what time it is. Also swiping the screen once three animals are displayed stops the game - and then requires the game to be restarted.

title: Incredibly fun and helpful!
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 15, 2018
content: This is such a creative skill. It gives you a short and sweet description of the animal and it's characteristics and tells you how to use their features to exercise. She stops every few animals to ask if you want a break and doesn't cycle through the same ones so there's always something new and exciting. The music is lively and the workout duration is short enough to keep a child engaged but long enough to tire them out after a few animals. I highly recommend this skill.

title: I love it, Kiddo Loves It
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 23, 2020
content: This one is a favorite. A lot of fun, doesn't require frequent cues to keep going, encourages kids to interact with chances to repeat phrases as if they were playing with family, friends, or teachers and then checks whether they want to keep playing if they don't repeat the game-related phrase prompted. Single easy voice commands "more" and "all done" can be used by even toddlers.Animal facts, music, and encouragement as they go all work alongside the fun workout (spinning, moving arms back and forth, jumping, etc and NO climbing)Works on standard Alexa/Echo devices and is an automatically allowed part of Freetime if you have a kids device with Freetime Enabled(You can also enable Freetime on any Echo device if you have a subscription from getting a kids edition Kindle Fire or kids dot or enrolling separately)

title: Scary if not prepared
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 10, 2020
content: This was not enabled on my devices nor was it even set up to be allowed. Girlfriend was sleeping while I was at work. Yesterday as she was sleeping, this came on and said something similar to "look behind you" or "I see you behind the bla bla" (according to her) - she was sleeping right next to alexa. She texts me and said "stop pranking me. That was not funny." I was confused as heck. I know about remote activation but I did not do that for sure. I looked at the history and nothing was activated or voice controlled.No idea how alexa just starts doing random stuff like that but this app will probably scare the Bejesus out of you if you're not playing the game. title: No instructions on how to connect kitchen to Alexa
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 11, 2021
content: No instructions came on how to set the kitchen up with Alexa. I spent almost an hour searching the Amazon Alexa App and the Amazon listing to see if there were any instructions. I had to visit the review section on the Kidkraft website to even find out what the first thing to do was and I figured the rest out from there.- Go to Settings in Amazon Alexa App- Choose Device Settings- Choose device you are going to be using with the Kidkraft Kitchen- Then pair Kidkraft Kitchen with your chosen echo device. The kitchen shows up as a bluetooth device.I hope this helps other parents out there! Now my sons can’t wait to play with it!

title: Fun twist on the original game
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 23, 2018
content: This is a creative use of voice interaction that turns tic tac toe from a game of strategy to one of memory, where you have to visualize the board as you play (or you/your kids can play with a piece of paper to play "traditionally" by marking Alexa's turns for her). Multiple difficulties allow for winnable games for players of any skill level, and the game is flexible with the words you use to describe the position you want, rather than strictly enforcing its own.The only missing feature I can think of is allowing Alexa to play first. Currently, the human player gets the first move every time. It'd be nice to the player and Alexa alternating first-moves in successive games ala traditional tic tac toe.

title: Cute, needs work, heres some tips
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 1, 2019
content: First Elmo is a tad hard to understand (its an app so what do you expect) but raise the volume via app and correct your settings to hear it better. Yes it could use clearer speaking. It also needs to slow down to allow children a chance to think about the answer in hide and seek. The call Elmo for the letter of the day is GREAT for my 3 yr old grandson. People complain about skill being stuck and cant move on to something else. There is a button in your app that says disable skill or speak "alexa exit sesame street" or "alexa disable skill". Works every time for us. But all in all my grandson wants to call Elmo every single day for the letter of the day and he repeats his sentence including letter of the day all day long. Great! 💖

title: What's he say?
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2018
content: Me: *enables skill*3yo: *Call Elmo*Elmo: * {Fuzzy, high-pitched audio that forensic scientists could not possibly discern into speech} *3yo, looking at me with confused look: *What's he say?"Me: He said it's time to disable this skill.I do love Sesame Street, but there are probably better representatives than Elmo, and definitely characters that are easier to understand.  In any case, like several story-time skills the audio is too poor for anybody to understand.

title: Idea is good, though there's much room for expansion.
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 17, 2020
content: "Letter of the Day" and "Find Elmo" are cute, however, this Alexa Skill could absolutely be more robust. Options like Elmo's joke of the day, Elmo singing (though Sesame Street music is available separately by requesting Alexa to play), Elmo exercise (stretching, dancing, etc) and games (Simon Says, etc) would allow children to be more interactive with the app. It is every toddler's beloved Elmo, WITHOUT screen time!  This suggestion has been submitted to the app developers. Fingers crossed!

title: Frustration plus!
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2021
content: as the headline says, this game represents about as much frustration as you could get from an Alexa scale.Frustration is an understatement. The game will tell you that it’s sunny and very warm and yet you will sell no lemonade. And then it will have many days of cloudiness which is fine however if you’re driving along and trying to play this game it’s frustratingly slow and does not give you the phone you’re looking for which is to configure your lemonade stand and see how many cups you sell based on the weather.The background sound is also frustrating because the sounds don’t match any of the weather. You’ll hear kids playing the same no matter what the weather is it was just an unnecessary feature.Do you sound like little peeves, but try it and you will understand.￼

title: Liked it, but too many problems. Upset.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 19, 2021
content: Every time I write this review, it cuts off. Amazon Alexa really doesn’t want other people to see bad reviews, doesn’t it? My review: Me and my daughter play this game every night before bed. Yeah, it’s cool and fun! But sometimes (Who am I kidding? Most of the time!) Alexa mishears and ruins our progress. This kind of ruins the game for us. Once I said $1 & 95 cents and Alexa gave out lemonade for free, and what was even more upsetting was we sold 6 cups, Another time, I said $1 & 75 cents and Alexa thought I said $1,000 (How do you even mistake that???) on a HOT DAY. I can’t. And the several reviews I tried to write? Amazon Alexa messed it all up. I wanted to give it 4 stars, then three stars, and now, I’m giving it two. Good luck trying to keep your sanity with this game. 😡😡😡

title: Pray to God
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2019
content: Mary was a human being who was born, as all humans are, with a sin nature and who recognized that she needed a Savior. In fact, the very passage used in the Hail Mary, known as Mary’s Magnificat (Luke 1:46-55), contains the declaration “my spirit rejoices in God my Savior,” a clear indication that she understood her need for a Savior from sin.The Bible never says that Mary was anyone but an ordinary human whom God chose to use in an extraordinary way. Yes, Mary was a righteous woman and favored (graced) by God (Luke 1:27-28). At the same time, Mary was a sinful human being who needed Jesus Christ as her Savior, just like everyone else (Ecclesiastes 7:20; Romans 3:23; 6:23; 1 John 1:8).Prayer to anyone other than God alone is anti-biblical. Praying to Mary or petitioning her to pray for us is against the Scriptures. Prayer is an act of worship. When we pray to God, we are admitting that we need His help. Directing our prayers to anyone other than God is robbing God of the glory that is His alone, something God hates and will not tolerate (Isaiah 42:8).While Mary was certainly a godly young woman greatly blessed in that she was chosen to bear the Savior of the world, she was not in any way divine, nor was she sinless, nor is she to be worshipped, revered, venerated, or prayed to.

But the reason I decided to share my review is because I have read several reviews that state they should make jf to where it turns off after awhile. you can achieve this by saying “alexa, stop playing in thirty minutes” or however long you choose! hope that helps :)

title: Poor Story Selection
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 12, 2018
content: At first both my 4-year-old son, and I were in love with this skill. He would listen to it for an hour at a time. However, the stories started repeating. Very few seem to be actual published books. The quality of the stories is poor. Lots of whining and even lying to adults in stories. The one where the boy and girl play pretend house is what got me to disable the skill. “Do you like my new yoga outfit, honey?” 🤢 Why have my kids listen to these crappy stories? Most characters display behaviors I wouldn’t want my kids to emulate.

title: DO NOT USE UNLESS YOU WANT TO BE CHARGED
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 18, 2019
content: this skill says it is free. theres nowhere it states it will charge your card. it charged me $76 for the damn skill.

title: Please make it STOP!!!
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 22, 2018
content: If we don’t remember to set the sleep timer before enabling the stories, Alexa just keeps telling more and more stories. Our kid never goes to sleep!Please revert to reading just ONE story. Do it for the parents!!

title: horrible update!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2021
content: There are two major issues with this update. First, my kids used to be able to open amazon storytime by themselves. Ever since this update, I now have go to each of my kids rooms and launch it. I have 4 kids. My wife is not even able to do it. Only me. That is unacceptable.Second, frequently, it will stop playing after one or two stories, which then makes me have to open it yet again for them.These two issues make this skill absolutely ridiculous, and a pain in the you know where to use. Only reason I still use it is because the Alexa voice telling the stories in the bedtime story skill is horrible and annoying. Has no emotion, and just drones on.Please fix ASAP.

title: Needs a way to stop remotely or at a certain time
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 18, 2018
content: This app is fantastic and my kids love it. They love it so much it keeps them awake until I go upstairs and shut it off... after more than an hour sometimes. This needs a timer of some sort or perhaps a custom story count (15 mins or so?) then turn it off.

title: Amazon story time
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 5, 2018
content: I love this skill because it has many funny, sad, scary, or happy stories that it can tell you. It can tell you audible or Amazon rapids. I prefer Amazon Rapids because it has a different voice for every character, where as Audible reads to you with one voice. So the stories from Amazon Rapids are more interesting and they are shorter than the Audible stories so, if you fall asleep listening to one it just turns off when it ends, which shouldn’t be long. Some of my favorite stories are the Danger and Eggs series, the tricky sitter, and the dad store. I hope you try out Amazon Rapids and I hope you enjoy!

title: These stories are inappropriate
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2021
content: Dark, negative, mean stories that will start effecting your child's outlook on life. I tried to be easy going about it because of WFH, but I notice my 5 year old says weird things that directly come from these stories. Mean characters, adult like sarcasm, death/killing conversations etc. Think its time to delete this

title: Worst Skill Ever Created
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 17, 2021
content: Ta Ta. See ya soon raccoon. My feedback should be focused on specific features of the "product". OK. Whoever is responsible for creating this skill should have realized that adding an utterance when you turn it off was a bad idea. Why. Because this is a bedtime skill and the last thing you want is for it to yell some unnecessary nonsense when you turn it off. Why. It risks waking your sleeping kids up. This skill was poorly thought-out and poorly planned. It's an absolute stain on the skills portfolio.

title: Son enjoys the stories, but they will play endlessly once started
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 23, 2021
content: While there are not a ton of stories (we've now heard all of them multiple times over the course of a few months), my son still enjoys them.The biggest problems are with regard to controlling it as a parent. As other reviewers have mentioned, it will play endlessly unless told to stop. Also, unlike some other skills, you cannot tell it to stop from another Alexa device (neither by voice on another Echo nor through the Alexa smartphone app). You're only option is to stop them from the device they are playing on, which can be a problem when your child is sleeping in that room. Sure, you can set device limits so that your child cannot use the device during certain time periods, but that's not a proper solution.

title: REPLY TO YOUR CUSTOMERS!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2021
content: clearly this update is frustrating and unwanted. but not giving an update is insulting and a bad customer experience. Either fix it or admit this is perminent change so we can stop trying to resolve.

title: Impossible to give permission
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2021
content: My kids have used this for years, all of a sudden we cant use it and are told a parent must give permission. OK, I'm the parent and my voice is mapped but you can't verbally give permission. "I have sent a link to the home page of your Alexa app" yup, there it is on my app home, great. I click the link and am given a choice to disable skill as a button or click a link for the terms of service, which are dated as last updated nearly 18 months ago, July 2020. From here one would expect the OK/enable/accept button or link but THERE IS NONE. I have spent 15 minutes going through the app, the web page.... there is NO METHOD to grant permission. Yet again Amazon has implemented code based on an incomplete use case that doesn't work. Great job folks. Just delete the skill if you don't support it, Amazon.

title: Works well but why flood it with bratty, disrespectful characters?
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 30, 2021
content: This app is working just fine for us. There have been no issues. The recording include varying voices and great sound effects. I think they've done a good job to start off with. They could continue on and expand I think.Some of the stories are cute and pretty creative and my 5 year old enjoys them. I do take major issue though with how so many of the characters have horrible attitudes, are extremely disrespectful to the parents, the friends or anyone else and there is no teaching moment or character development. The kids in the story just get to be nasty and mean or bratty and that's it. I've taken the time to explain that it is never ok to treat someone like those characters do and how to handle it when he is spoken to like that because yes, in real life that happens often. I just don't think "storytime" is the time to be flooded with it Amazon. Seriously.PLEASE AMAZON, put stories on your app for kids that have kids that are KIND to their friends, love their family members, learn something wholesome, or learn conflict resolution or just have FUN! It doesn't have to be a big, in-depth, spell it out for them, sappy thing.  The characters don't need to be mean for the listeners to be engaged. There are much more uplifting stories out there I know it.I really hope you guys listen to the many reviews with these concerns. I think Storytime is a fantastic idea and you're doing a great job with delivery. Please give us some better characters.

title: I love and hate this...
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 25, 2019
content: My kids love Amazon storytime. Even if we read to them, which we regularly do, it's a good way to get them to bed. They enjoy the stories, even though it doesn't seem like there's a lot of depth (yet) for each type, the pool of story types seems to be getting wider though, which is good.I like that more than one story plays now, it send to get the kids to sleep faster.Here's what I don't like:*It takes a bit of time to turn on. Alexa doesn't always hear them say 'family' or 'bedtime' when they say the type of story either.*It's really loud when you ask it to stop. I have verbose mode off, but ending storytime is practically a story itself. It's enough that my five year old has been roused from her sleep more than once.*There's no good way to turn it off quietly from my phone or another Alexa device. I most often go into my kids room and unplug the device. It's the fastest and quietest way to stop it. Please give us a quick way to stop this immediately (and quietly) from a smartphone or another echo enabled device. [Edit] I have recently been able to stop the storytime mode from another device. It also makes the announcement that it's stopping on the device that heard you. Great improvement! [/Edit]

title: How does this have bad reviews???
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 17, 2020
content: my kids have been listening to Amazon storytime for a very long time now (every single night) we've never had any issues with permissions, access, or bugs. my ONLY complaint is that they have now listened to (and have memorized) every story - although it doesn't seem to bother my kids. I wish Amazon would continue to add content.

title: Cute but not "stories" by definition
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 16, 2019
content: A "story" has a beginning, middle and end and includes narration.  These are better defined as radio shows or audio plays.  There is no narration, so at times it is difficult to imagine what is going on in the scene of the 'story'.  I would call this skill "Children's radio shows" or "Audio plays"  not bedtime stories..

title: Read by actors, we all love it!!
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 26, 2018
content: I was skeptical and wondered if the stories were read by Alexa as is the case with other apps. The stories are told with sound effects and narrated by actors! This sounds more like professionally read book on tape. Great addition to bedtime!

Alexa already has all their info. My children love stories from Alexa, Amazon is changing the world, and I think its just silly that this app has any bad ratings, the stories are fun and age appropriate. Don't be scared lol. It'll be OK.

title: *Not Impressed*
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2021
content: Asked for a mystery for my 12 yr old granddaughter and what I got was about a 3 minute story for a 4 yr old. about a mama chick who lost her eggs, asked for help from a policeman who found them hatched behind the chicken coop. Then the chicks stole his glasses. The End. I'm guessing it was meant to be cute but fell way short. First of all I expected a real story. Secondly, there's no way a 3 minute story is holding any kids interest.  Stories are usually meant for quiet time, naptime and bedtime. Three minutes won't do diddly. If I have to load story after story every 3-5 minutes I may as well read a story myself.  At least it will be worth listening to and long enough to put the kid to sleep. Lastly the voices were terrible. The mama chick sounded like a man trying to sound like a woman. Sooo sad. Well Amazon you really missed the boat on this one. A great opportunity tossed into the wind. Such a disappointment.....it should be scrapped and start over. Honestly Amazon, I'm embarrassed for you.

title: No Option to Playback Story by Title or Author
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 20, 2022
content: As of now, there is no feature that enables users to playback a specific story title from the Storytime skill.  My daughter falls asleep with Storytime stories nearly every night, but she is at the age where she wants to hear everything over & over again.  It has been proven that children listen to, play, & watch their favorite media on repeat because it helps with their cognitive development, allowing them to analyze & process words & ideas with each repeated playback. Not to mention that a familiar, safe story is a great way to fend off potential nightmares. However, Amazon Storytime only allows you to select the category of story (animals, princesses, superheros, silly, etc.), or randomize the story selection by "spinning the wheel."  What is missing is the ability to replay specific Story Titles, or even authors of favored stories, directly from the voice-activated skill.  Something like, "Alexa, open Storytime to Animals, and play the story 'The Thing'!" Or "Alexa, open Storytime. [category prompt] Author Brad White's titles."  That added feature would bump this up to a 5-star review from us!

title: Keep updating to keep 5 stars! Our kids 3 and 8 love it!
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 12, 2019
content: I bet it's difficult to please all these parents since the reviews often include requests for opposite things.  Could you include your website/e-mail so we can provide more detailed feedback requests? Also I bet many, including myself, would love to help your team develop more stories and make this skill a huge success.  Here are some issues and ideas to solve them in the meantime:1. Stories don't work for all ages:**Have 3 or 4 age groups for child to choose from first. Then they can choose type of story.2.  Announcer between stories is loud and disruptive:**When first starting this skill, Alexa can say "if you'd like to make changes during storytime but don't know how, just say "Alexa, what are my storytime options.""**Or between stories Alexa could WHISPER a very short sentence to about options.3.  Stories play all night and never stop: (personally we like this because the abrupt stop wakes my child up. Go figure.)**When skill first starts, ask child how many stories they'd like to hear.**Allow us to go to a website to personalize the skill with age group and amount of stories.**Allow us to use the LOOP function we use in many other skills. LOOP means the stories will continue non-stop.4. Bedtime stories aren't all good for bedtime. Many have too much action, loud voices and stimulating stories:**Age group would put quieter stories in the youngest age group.**Or...child/parent could ask for soothing, relaxing or active bedtime stories.**Youngest age group bedtime stories would ask a child/parent whether they'd like the stories read by single person (less stimulating) or characters.  Or we go to the website to personalize this how we want it.Thanks for listening! Contact me if you are hiring readers.

title: Why did this stop working?
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 11, 2020

title: Wonderful but some issues

content: We love this skill, as it has completely changed our kids bedtime routine.  I would give it 5 stars except it has started interrupting itself when it tells you to say “Alexa open Storytime”.  The whole thing pauses because Alexa is spoken.  Also since we use it for bedtime there is a story where the characters sing and it is the most awful thing in the world - wakes my daughter up every time.  Also, when my daughter is asleep and we fell Alexa to stop, it says quite loudly “bye bye butterfly” which often causes the kids to wake up or stir as well.  Other than these few issues, which weren’t present until a short time ago, we absolutely love this and it has been a bedtime lifesaver.

title: Best Alexa Skill Ever
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 2, 2020
content: We use this skill every single night.  It is part of our routine and helps out 6 year old wind down by himself by listening to these stories. At 6 he knows how to skip stories, turn it off and put on his musical spa music for bed.  We have his echo set to turn off completely at 10 pm so if we forget it’s not going all night.  His favorites are “Family” and “School.”  But we also like the holiday ones and LEGO ones.  It’s been over a year and he still listens for 20-30 minutes a night, every night.

title: 1..2..3 & A B C
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2017
content: Is how easy Amazon made enabling Storytime fun to do for me!  Thank you Amazon my nieces loved storytime and are excited to hear more.Not sure why some customers felt a bit frustrated with the set up other than maybe reading too fast and misunderstanding the content. It really only took a minute. Here are steps without all the extra. Hope this helps ☺1. Click on tab "Grant Parental Permission"2. Click on Enable Skill3. Enter verification code to identify you, sent by Amazon  A. By choosing to have code sent to you by text "OR"  B. By you choosing to enter your AMZN credit card pinThat's it!

title: Too few stories, most of mediocre quality.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2018
content: Most of the stories are actually more like skits, with only dialogue and no narration or storyline. Having listened to them many times now because they repeat (there are only so many stories, so after a month I'd heard them all). Way too many stories with kids bickering, annoying fake kid voices, or just straight up bad role models.Most stories aren't *so* terrible, they're more innocuous and forgettable, some droll, some inspid. My kids did like it enough, but I disabled it after hearing the same "stories" (again, most are like skits with just dialogue). The breaking point was a brother and sister exchange with an (often used) annoying fake kid voice and nothing but bickering. I hear that enough in my own house without it coming out of the Echo.I really think it would be better if they had more real stories from Audible. However, for whatever reason, my kids tend to skip the "real" stories and just want to listen to the skits. It would also be much better if there were more in general, so I didn't have to hear the same stories, good or bad, over and over.Edit: somehow the kids managed to get it back, even though I disabled the skill from my phone.

title: Parental Permission Glitch Fixed
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 22, 2020
content: If your skill keeps asking for parental permission, try deleting the voice profiles that your echo uses. Now the Echo does not know who is talking, but at least story time is working again.

title: Personal Information = Credit Card Info
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2017
content: I was excited about this app and might have go through with enabling it if hadn't felt like I was being duped.Before enabling the skill you get the following notice:"For experiences like kid skills, we need permission to collect personal information, including voice recordings. Your permission will apply to all kid skills and other Amazon kid services."I thought that was odd, but okay. When I was asked to sign in to my Amazon account I thought it was weird, but again, this Amazon Echo, so ok.Then I was asked for my credit card security code (cvv number) that was the last red flag and I canceled the skill.I don't know if it is on the up and up, but it seems a bit sketchy.

title: stop complaining
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 1, 2021
content: I see a lot of negative comments towards amizon about this feature, a feature I dont use by the way. The only problem I see is a bunch of complaining parents who dont have a babysitter for bedtime. If you cant stop for 10min to personally spend quality 1 on 1 time with your children before bed, then the problem is you not amizon. We wonder why children are acting the way they do now of days, well heres an example of why. Children need to be read to, they need quality 1 on 1 time each day or their going to act out and much worse as time goes on. I find it hard to believe that not 1 parent finds it wrong that alexa is reading to your child and not the parent. That is so sad for so many reasons, I enjoy that nighttime 1 on 1 time with my children, thats our time and after a busy day we both need that quality time together. We wonder why children of this generation act the way they do. Heres a perfect example of why, shame on all of you for complaining about amizon and not looking at yourselves as the problem instead for not taking 10 min to be with your children, who desperately need that 1 on 1 time. Electronics are not parents and their not babysitters, people try being parents instead and read to your children yourself instead of letting alexa do your job for you. Shame on all of you, everyone knows children who are personally read to enjoy reading more and succeed more. Shame on you for stunting your kids growth personally and academically. Be a parent.

title: Niko and the Sword of Light is pretty racist
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 5, 2021
content: My son loves this skill and listens to the stories all the time.  It keeps him busy so I let it happen. Most of the stories are mediocre. There is this one story, though, under the "adventure" category of stories called Niko and the Sword of Light (or something close to that) and it is SO RACIST. I always skip it for him when it comes on and try to explain the problem with it to him.The evil villain voice has a strong Black American accent and the whole story has strong associations with goodness as "light" and evil as "dark." The result is incredibly racist.  You can do better Amazon. Come on.  This is 2021. This story sounds like it came out of 1940s assumptions about race.

title: Counts slowly out loud--perfect for exercises
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 25, 2019
content: Update: Thank you developers for returning the slow  counting speed back to its previous slow speed. This app is the ONLY one available that simply counts out loud. Not a stopclock, not a metronome, not a child' learn numbers tool. I'm back to happily giving this app a 5-star review.Previous: I've been happily using this app for over a year to count reps for some exercises I do and up until today, I would have given it a 5 star review. I liked that I could ask the count to be VERY SLOW. Today, that slow speed has dramatically increased, preventing me from being able to complete a weight lift in time before the next number is counted. Developer, please revert to the timing speed you used prior to today.

title: please confirm with a parental "UNIT"
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 24, 2016
content: it's basic . .. and asks:"is your room tidy?"  if you answer Yes, it next asks:"have you practiced your instrument?"  if you answer Yes, it next asks:"is your homework done?"  if you answer Yes, it next asks:"are your chores done?"  if you answer Yes, it next asks:"do you have screen time (TV) privileges?"  if you answer Yes, it says"congratulation you have screentime, please confirm with a parental unit."if you answer No, it says "No Screens for you" ...I about fell on the floor laughing when it said please confirm with a parental "UNIT".I hate to brag but I, yes me, She Who is Unnamed, I, invented the phrase parental unit, I started saying that well OVER 35 plus years ago. That's why I am laughing. And why I added an extra 🌟. But a 3 star rating is because, as follows:if adjusting the questions were available this would be better, considering every student doesn't play an instrument, and since a majority of schools have eliminated their music programs, and every child who might want to play an instrument doesn't always have access to instruments to practice, but they might have something else that the ability to change or adjust "practice" here would apply, or be able to insert options for special projects in addition to homework...  also, customizing options, to be able to adjust by person... Not all children are the same, even in the same family.  But this is an awesome starting for an app of this type. wish this was availaible when my kids were little - 25 plus years too late - one last side note would be to add features for grandma's, for when the little ones visit.

title: There's just no substitute for real parenting
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 24, 2016
content: Dev clearly does not have children. What's stopping the kid from saying yes to all questions just to get screen time? Better yet, what's stopping the kid from just turning on the TV? Alexa? I don't think so. Who's going to do quality control? "Did you do your HW?" "Yes" "Did you answer all questions? Let me see/check." Oh wait, you can't. Technology can make your life easier but in this case it just can't replace a real parent.

title: This is The Perfection

title: Had to give permission like 7 times
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 11, 2017
content: 1) Launch the app to give permission2) Are you sure you want to give permissions?3) All of your children listed here will have access, are you still sure?4) Alright then, enter your password to give permission.5) Now enter the code sent to your phone to give permission.6) Great now press OK to give permission again!7) I've sent you an email confirming you've given permission.At this point, I'm pretty sure it's easier to give permission for a nuclear launch than it is to open this app... Now that we're in, the app seems kinda fun, but now I'm worried about what exactly I've given permission for. If takes 7 steps to confirm, there must have been some malicious fine print... I'll play the game, then disable the skill, just in case.Update: kids loved the game, so giving it an extra star.

title: Oh What Fun it is to hear Santa!
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 24, 2021
content: When I received an email that there was a Hey Santa personality for our Echo dots I was amused and just had to try it.  Love it!  I have a 4th generation dot in the living room and a 3rd generation echo show in the kitchen, both Hey Santa enabled.  We are all adults here in the household but Santa is fun to communicate with for sure.  I've read the other reviews and just have to shake my head at the people who probably have the older version of the Echo and are ranting because the Hey Santa doesn't work on their dots, they really need to take up reading and see that there is a notation that the personality doesn't work on some devices.  Anyway I am looking forward to Santa sharing some Christmas songs and chatter later today.

title: Great stories and music for Christmas
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 16, 2021
content: This was a little clumsy to get downloaded - I don't love having to pull up an app to make something work. But once it was ready to go, it was a big hit! Santa sounds great and is pretty funny. My family really loves that he tells them stories, especially the ones about holiday traditions around the world and some fun food things. They keep asking for more and more. It's a nice Christmas freebie for sure!

Done, in the app, the skill shows with the option of disabling, my echoes say nope not enabled and list other Santa skills but not this one again.  Unhappy kid.

title: Looks like something written during an Amazon Developer Day
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2015
content: Another Amazonian cranking out a skill.Ease of Use: 3 out of 5. In the past I've given full marks to trivial interfaces. I'm changing my mind now. There isn't really anything to this interface, therefore there wasn't actually any design in it. So from this skill forward I'm only giving trivial interfaces neutral marks.Ironically, this will pull this skill up.Usefulness: 1 out of 5. This does exactly what it says. It takes a name, and mangles it in some child's rhyme. The problem is that the pacing is off, much like when it reads Knock-Knock jokes (which is why my skill breaks it up!) The most fun I had with this was trying to tick Alexa into saying dirty words.Novelty: 2 out of 5. OK, so no one has done a word mangling skill before. I'm not really sure this is a bad thing. Maybe translating into pig latin is next.Overall: 1 out of 5. This looks and plays like something someone thought of and wrote during an Amazon Developer Day. It took almost no effort to do, and really doesn't achieve much.

title: Is this just random?
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 28, 2018
content: I guess if you want Alexa to randomly assign chores to a list of people this would work for you. I was looking for Alexa to keep track of whose turn it actually IS to do something among my 3 kids, so it being random doesn’t work for us. I just don’t want the kids arguing every day about whose turn it is to do a specific chore (we rotate) so wish I could set up a chore rota and Alexa could keep track. This doesn’t seem to do this...and there are no instructions anywhere so I have no idea how it works or how to set it up.

title: Doesn't work
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 28, 2018
content: I was able to add helpers for the question "Whose turn is it to do the dishes". From there on, it is a crapshoot to figure out what Alexa will do. Some of the time it picks a random name from the helpers list (where can I make this a recurrent weekly list for each helper??), another time "Sorry, I'm not sure". The next time "Table wear are dishes, …" then goes on some random rant about completely useless information about the restaurant industry. Then "Hmmm, I don't know that one". Really?? And I got an email today from Amazon touting the benefits of the "Whose turn" app. Shouldn't you guys make sure it works before mass-emailing your customers about an app (with a great potential) that does not work?

title: Terrible
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 8, 2020
content: It recorded some words as my list of people that were not names. I had it read me my list of names and then repeated it back exactly saying the name the same way that it was read to me. I Tried reading it fast, I tried really annunciating, nothing worked. I just got a message back saying that that name was not on my list. it's also really annoying that I have to tell Alexa to open it before I can use it. It would be better if I could just say Alexa, whose turn is it... and it knew what to do.

title: Needs to add more than random answers
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2018
content: Given that the initializing process required my family member names, I was surprised that it did not recognize their names.  Also, I was looking for the program to actually track on which day it was a person’s turn to do something.  Instead, it just randomly responds with someone who has their name in the list.

title: Can't Edit list of people Selects same child - repetitively
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 30, 2020
content: My children were speaking when I was adding their names. It add “At People” and “Dry Turn” as part of the list of people to select from. I tried to remove these names and it keeps saying, “Turn is not in your list of people, “ or “Apple is not in your list of people.” Therefore I can not edit the list to select from. It is also a random selection. It keeps selecting the same child over and over. It doesn’t switch turns often and is ” NOT FAIR” - Just ask my kid. At first I told him ”thats life” but after it continuing for so long now I can't help but to agree with him.

title: Won’t learn names?
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 4, 2021
content: Added my first child with no problems. For my 2nd child it jist kept saying “whoa whoa slow down. I cant tell what you’re saying.” She has a common name and i was soeaking slowly. Never could get it to work.

title: Doesn't recognize names well
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 28, 2018
content: My son's nickname is Manny and my daughter's name is Naya. Manny was Mandy and Naya was Noella (smh). I tried multiple times but this would not recognize their names when trying to add helpers. Also their names are on my Alexa/Amazon app but it still doesn't know. I guess if your kids have general names this will work fine. It's a shame it didnt work. Every time i asked to access the skill Alexa kept saying we, "needed mediation" whatever that means. This was after I accepted her names for my children. Hassle to try to set up. Not worth the frustration.

title: My kids love Monty!!!
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 24, 2021
content: My oldest daughter was scared of monsters in her closet when she was 5 or 6 and this didn't exist then...  She eventually grew out of it, but I can't tell you how many nights her pragmatic dad tried to explain that monsters don't exist. It was the same conversation night after night for about a year.Now my youngest is 6 and its happening all over again.  Both our girls have Dots in their rooms so I decided to search for something that might help.  There are a couple of monster type skills, but this is by far, hands down the best.  Monty is so lovable and trustworthy and the way he 'activates' the room is nothing short of genius.  It varies slightly night after night so it doesn't feel taped.  Credit to the company who thought this one up.  Great job!

title: Brilliant concept, super cute and creative!
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 24, 2021
content: Our issue at the moment is more that dinosaurs are lurking around the dark shadows of the house, but not monsters anymore, thanks to Monster Guard! Quick, easy for our kids to chat with Monty and make sure no monsters are hiding in their rooms when they go to bed, and even cooler that they can activate the monster guard to keep them out all night. Kudos to whoever thought of this neat idea!

title: Absolutely fantastic
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 30, 2021
content: Gives my toddler assurance there are no monsters. Would be nice to have an all around bad guy scanner. No need to assume child is gonna right to bed.

title: Great skill idea
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 26, 2017
content: My kid needs help with her multiplication tables, so this is awesome.  Simple enough to work.  I only have two issues (or maybe it's one in the same).  The game seems to randomly stop.  Also, if she doesn't give an answer fast enough the game stops and she has to restart it.  I like the activation phrase.  It's simple and easy to remember.  I'd like to see some score keeping ability or incentive (badges for perfecting a table).  I'd also like for her to remember which ones my kids got wrong and repeat them randomly until they are correct.  Maybe have a kid profile option.  Overall, a nice app.

title: Stops working
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2018
content: The skill just shuts off and we have to keep restarting it. The other annoying part (to me ) is that between every  answer Alexa gives a phrase or word of praise.  If they could cut that out to only give a " great job" after a set of 5 or 10,  that would be better. We are going to disable the skill now,  but will check back to see if there are updates/fixes later and would try it again then.

title: It works!
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 18, 2020
content: Sooo, yes I was also having issues. (If you have the skill already enabled, disable it). Log out of your Amazon account from whatever device you are using,.....then open the Alexa App and enable the skill...it should prompt you to enter your password..enter it. Now the skill is enabled and ready for use. Close the App. Ask Alexa to open Disney Stories on the device you want to use. (The device shouldn't say "...give permission...).

title: Works great for my kids, good selection and recognition of stories and characters
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 20, 2020
content: This skill was easy to set up and enable for my kids, and they love being able to choose the story they want. Whether my older kid chooses a story by name, or the younger one calls out a favorite character, the skill knows what to do.

title: 4 stories
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 23, 2020
content: seriously,only 4 stories. so lame!

title: Needs some work
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 29, 2021
content: The concept is fantastic, however the execution could use some work. I think most parents would agree that being able to control this skill via phone, silently would be a plus. Especially for trying to get kids down. Even better would be the ability to create a "playlist" of sorts in routines. This way we could set up a "story hour" of sorts.

title: 6 year old loves this skill
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 15, 2020
content: We have Free Time Unlimited. My 6 year old loves this skill. Works just fine. She says "Alexa, read me a Disney story" and it opens up and asks what kind of story she wants to hear.

title: Want more stories? Get Amazon Kids+
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 23, 2021
content: The first month is free and then for one child profile, it's $2.99 a month for Prime members. It plays all 100 Disney Stories! Plus with Amazon Kids+, there's videos, interactive games, educational skills, Audible books, and more. This is so worth it, compared to just getting the 4 free Disney Stories. 😊

title: During a Hatd Time. We Appreciate Alexa! 💛
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 20, 2020
content: Very enjoyable it increases a creative imagination, instead of staring at a tv screen all day. Helps entertain the children during this hard time of covid19. Keeps the children hopeful and inspired. Even keeping their minds, distracted from the distress of not being in school. Alexa is a great inspiration and hope. Thank you so much!

Please work out the kinks in this program.  This is by far the worse feature or skill on Prime, however a great concept.  I have Fire TV, Echo, and Echo Show.
